title.narrative: PRIDE / Headquarters

description.narrative: Working towards diverse and inclusive societies in which LGBTI are able to participate to their full potential

activity-date.narrative: The 16 PRIDE countries are located in the Asian, Caribbean, Sub-Saharan African and MENA regions. COC does not disclose countries and partners as described in its exclusion policy. General information per region and in a thematic section is available under the respective activities here in IATI.

recipient-country.narrative: COC does not disclose countries and partners according to its exclusion policy. 38 partners are contracted while more partners are still being selected. This is done in close cooperation with the Dutch embassies responsible for the given country.

description.narrative: PRIDE
Total Incoming commitment for POP 2021
Total Incoming funds for POP 2021
Total Incoming funds for POP 2022
Total Incoming funds for POP 2022

title.narrative: Exclusion Policy COC
Capable Community Based Organisations

description.narrative: Capable LGBTI organisations are essential in terms of supporting individual LGBTI people, giving a voice to the LGBTI community and aligning with different players in the broader LGBTI movement. They need to function at an “operational minimum” before they can start doing advocacy effectively.

title.narrative: DD6 DD6: Number of CBOs participating in PRIDE.

description.narrative: This indicator measures all partners under PRIDE for the given year.

comment.narrative: Unique number of CBOs participating under the PRIDE program, for the entire program duration.

title.narrative: Number of CBOs trained on sustainable revenue streams.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. Through different approaches, such capacities are built on topics relevant for creating strong and sustainable organisations. This indicators measures the number of organisations and groups supported by COC in developing their financial management capabilities. These skills have been developed through trainings on organisational finances, fundraising, auditing, bookkeeping. This indicator also counts those organisations who have been successful in obtaining additional funds through the help of COC.

title.narrative: DD5 DD5: Number of CBOs improving their capacities under PRIDE.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. This indicator measures all unique organisations who underwent a training on organisational development, financial management, L&A and/or were supported to attend events or conferences where they built on their skills through participation and engagement. Note that this indicator also counts those organisations not funded by PRIDE but are trained by partners in-country.

comment.narrative: In 2018, PRIDE tried a new approach to capacity building by ensuring the attendance of all related and non-contractual CSOs in the country, to provide a wider reach beyond the direct partners under PRIDE. This indicator for 2018 includes the data gathered on all unique attendees who were part of capacity building sessions, trainings and workshops.
The total number of unique CBOs that have improved capacities through the PRIDE program, starting 2017.

title.narrative: Number of CBOs trained on governance and leadership skills.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. Through different approaches, such capacities are built on topics relevant for creating strong and sustainable organisations. This indicators measures the number of organisations and groups supported by COC in developing their governance and leadership skills. These skills have been developed through trainings on organisational management, statutes, codes of conduct, communications and branding.

title.narrative: Number of CBOs trained on lobby and advocacy strategies.

description.narrative: COC supports grassroots LGBTI organisations and CBOs in multiple countries to build their capacities and develop a strong LGBTI-led and focussed civil society base in-country. Through different approaches, such capacities are built on topics relevant for creating strong and sustainable organisations. This indicators measures the number of organisations and groups supported by COC in developing their lobby and advocacy strategies. These strategies have been developed through trainings on advocacy tactics, lobbying methods etc.

title.narrative: Global Human Rights Movement.

description.narrative: Holding governments accountable when they violate or fail to uphold international human rights treaties to which they have committed greatly increases the pressure for change. To do this, we need strong and capable national and global LGBTI movements.

title.narrative: DD3 DD3: Number of recommendations, concluding observations and resolutions with references to broader human rights and gender-inclusive development that are accepted by states.

description.narrative: This indicator is the number of recommendations, concluding observations and resolutions (supported under PRIDE) that are formally accepted or noted by governments at adoption meetings and can be held accountable to.

comment.narrative: Accepted 18, Noted 43
statement accepted or noted at: UPR Uzbekistan UPR Bangladesh UPR Azerbijan UPR Cameroon UPR Senegal UPR Congo UPR Central African Republic UPR Belize

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of LGBTI activists supported in engaging at international and regional spaces, trained on L&A techniques etc.

description.narrative: This indicator measures the number of unique activists who built their L&A capacities, either through trainings and/or engagement and attendance at conferences, international political spaces. If an organisation is supported, then the people from the organisation are counted as individual activists under the pretext that skills are individually imparted and remain with individuals regardless of the organisation where they work.

comment.narrative: As a result of all activities, sessions, trainings and workshops around L&A, an estimate of 640 unique participants were included.

title.narrative: DD3 DD3: Number of statements, shadow reports and other reports (Yogyakarta, UN Special Procedures) around broader human rights and gender-inclusive development that have been drafted, signed, supported and/or provided consultation to by activists and CSOs.

description.narrative: Number of statements, shadow reports and other reports (Yogyakarta, UN Special Procedures) around broader human rights and gender-inclusive development that have been drafted, signed, supported and/or provided consultation to by activists and CSOs.

comment.narrative: Joint statements at 1) the Clustered interactive dialogue with the Special Rapporteur on the independence of judges and lawyers, and the Special Rapporteur on violence against women, 2) at the Interactive dialogue with the Working Group on discrimination against women during the 35th Human Rights Council session taking place in Geneva. Joint statement on abortion under the General Debate, Item 8, at the 36th Human Rights Council session

Statements signed on SRHR and composition of US delegation during CSW Broader statements to HLPF on SDGs under review and Leave No One Behind including reference also to SOGI by several Major Groups During HRC 37 COC made a joint statement on fear of repraisals with ILGA World, Amnesty International, ISHR and UPR-Info

Women's Rights Caucus statement on postponement CSW Beijing+25 declaration civil society, CSW Signed on to international civl society statement opposing US Commission on Unalienable Rights Civil society statement on civil society participation in virtual UN meetings during Covid_19 Civil society statement on postponement of all Treaty Body reviews in 2020 Joint letter Dutch civil society for international solidarity in context of COVID-19 - Parliament and government Joint letter Dutch civil society for halting budget cuts on development funding - Parliament and government Input to Dutch government delegation in 4 rounds of negotiations on Political Declaration CSW 64 Joint letter Dutch civil society on the 'first come first serve' principle MoFA call for Strong and Inclusive civil society engagement at UN Virtual Meetings, MGoS & WMG, President of ECOSOC, co-facilitators, President UNGA SRHR UHC paper to Dutch Parliament Joint letter BMO to Dutch Parliament on AIV advice COVID-19 response Joint letter BMO to Dutch Parliament on Dutch Human Rights Policy

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of statements, shadow reports and other reports (Yogyakarta, UN Special Procedures) on SOGIESC and LGBTI issues that have been drafted, signed, supported and/or provided consultation to, by activists and CSOs.

description.narrative: Same as title.

comment.narrative: Input on SOGIESC issues from partners for the consultation that fed into two reports (HRC/GA) of the SOGI Independent Expert Input on SOGIESC issues from partners for the country visit of the Special Rapporteur on Housing to Egypt During HRC37 COC made a statement (joined by RFSL) as part of the interactive dialogue with the Special Rapporteur for Human Rights Defenders LGBTI sensitization training organised by ISHR on 30-11-2018 for Special Rapporteurs: IE SOGI, SR HRDs, SR cultural rights, SR Truth, SR Freedom of Association and Assembly, SR summary executions, SR on Freedom of Expression Input and factsheets on SOGIESC inclusive language for CSW negotiations to Agreed Conclusions LBTI written statement to CSW SOGI Core Group of States statement at HLPF SOGI inclusive questions to states during Voluntary National Reviews, HLPF Input on SOGIESC issues to Womens Major Group to SDGs under review position papers and Leaving No One Behind statement on behalf of WMG and LGBTI stakeholder group ERC civil society statement and goals to states at the Equal Rights Coalition conference, Vancouver Input into Donor Coordination Working Group, National laws and policies Working Group and to Conference hosts Canada and Chile of the ERC SOGIESC report on gender-based violence to the Council of Europe - Istanbul Convention YP+10 report in cooperation with partners in MENA and EECA Central Asian LGBTI civil society statements on discrimination and violence at HDIM 2018 During HRC 37 COC delivered statements at the UPR outcomes sessions of Ukraine, Ghana, Sri Lanka and Pakistan on behalf of local CSOs During HRC 38 COC delivered a joint statement of Freedom of Expression with ISHR During HRC 38 COC delivered a joint statement on summary executions in Iraq on behalf of local CSO During HRC 38 COC delivered a statement at the UPR Outcomes session of Botswana on behalf of local organization During HRC 38 Joined a statement on Violence and Discrimination against LBTI women with ILGA World During HRC 38 COC delivered a statement on freedom of Association and Assembly During HRC 39 COC delivered statements on the UPR outcomes sessions of Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan

LBTI Caucus statement on CSW postponement LBTI Caucus manifesto on Generation Equality Action Coalition (Beijing+25) Paper on impact of COVID-19 on LGBTI communities - Dutch Foreign Office, embassies and other NGOs Oral intervention at UN Special Procedures meeting on impact of COVID-19 on LGBTI Written input for report on COVID-19 impact on participation of LGBTI human rights defenders in Human Rights Council Input to statement Equal Rights Coalition on COVID-19 and LGBTI (via Dutch MFA) Joint statement on COVID-19 and LGBTI to Human Rights Council Appeal to members of Dutch Parliament for inclusive humanitarian relief - COVID-19 and LGBTI Input to ERC Strategy 2020 - 2025 and co-chairs workplan Position Paper LGBTI Stakeholder Group HLPF 2021 Letter to promote protection for Iranian LGBTI Asylum Seekers NLD Joint statement & MPI event on COVID-19 and SRHR, including LGBTI to Dutch Parliament + Youth Ambassor input Report NAP 1325 Gender norms, masculinity & intersectionality (Nationaal Actieplan Vrouwen, Vrede & Veiligheid) joint submission on LGBTI to FoAA on women & girls Statement Public Consultations UN IE Older Persons on SOGIESC inclusion in mandate reporting Statement ID Freedom of Religion HRC 43 on combating hatred against LGBTI people UPR Outcomes statement Egypt UPR Outcomes statement Iraq Statement ID UN HC on human rights LGBTI Phillippines HRC 44 Statement ID UN HC on impacts of the COVID19 pandemic on LGBTI persons HRC 44 Statement ID WG Discrimination agaist Women on ending anti-rights action of conservative religious groups against transgender women HRC 44 Statement ID SR Violence against Women on human rights of LBTI women in Bulgaria and Equador HRC 44

Statement during the consultation of the SOGI Independent Expert by Aizhan K. on SOGIESC issues in Central Asia Statement on the UPR outcomes by COC/TNN/NNID (Netherlands), Arus Pelangi (Indonesia) and Mawjoudin (Tunisia) at the HRC UPR Stakeholder reports by Tunisia, Indonesia, Ukraine, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Ghana and Botswana 2 joint Statement during Item 3: Interactive Dialogue Independent Expert on violence and discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity; and the Special Rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions at HRC35 in Geneva Submission for the 10 Year Anniversary Review of the Yogyakarta Principles: Perspective from LGBTI organizations from Eastern Europe, Central Asia, the Middle East and North Africa.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of embassies that have been trained, sensitised and/or provided consultations to on LGBTI issues.

description.narrative: Same as title, cumulative indicator.

comment.narrative: For the Human Rights Course in July 2017 COC together with the LGBTI focal point of MoFA, train new embassy personnel that acquire a human rights position within an embassy on SOGIESC issues and the LGBTI foreign policy of MoFA.

Guyana (embassy based in Surinam) advised to support two Guyanese LGBTI organisations submissions for funding from ERA fund Embassy Chad on emergency situation LGBTI officer on legal and policy situation in Surinam - ERC strategy to approach potential new members Dutch embassy Baku advised to support in kidnapping case of LBQ woman 19 PMs to UN HRC advised on SOGIESC recommendations Kenya, Kyrgyzstan and Lesotho for UPR 35 23 PMs to UN HRC advised on SOGIESC recommendations Malawi and Mongolia for UPR 36 26 PMs to UN HRC advised on SOGIESC recommendations Myanmar, St. Lucia and St. Kitts for UPR 37 Advise to Dutch PM UN HRC on intersex statement HRC 45 Advise to Dutch PM UN HRC on possible sports resolution HRC 45

Permanent Mission of the Netherlands, Sweden, Spain, Chili, Slovenia, France, Finland, Mexico, Belgium, Canada, US, Australia, Norway, Switzerland, Israel, Italy, Portugal, Austria, Czech Republic, Argentina, Uruguay, Honduras, South Africa, Iceland and Ireland in Geneva consulted on issues of all UPR SOGIESC Advocacy Week participants Human Rights Course for staff of Embassies of the Netherlands who will aquire a (new) human rights post in 2018, those diplomats whom attended the training were sensitised on LGBTI issues and the LGBTI foreign policy of the Netherlands. Permanent Missions to UN in New York and government agencies: Netherlands, EU, UK, Argentina, Chile, USAID on issues related to CSW and SDGs Advice to and invitation to meetings with Canadian government and civil society set up by Dutch Embassy to Canada Permanent OSCE Missions of Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Canada, Iceland, Montenegro, Norway, Switzerland and the United States of America on discrimantion and violence against LGBTI in Central Asia during HDIM 2018 Advice to Dutch embassy in Moscow on renewed persecutions in Chechnya Advice to Dutch Human rights ambassador on LGBTI rights in China, South Africa, Hungary and Ethiopia. Permanent Missions to UN in New York of the EU, LGBTI Core Group, Groups of Asian and MENA countries on current state of LGBTI rights globally Advice to Dutch embassy in Baku on arbitrary arrests of LGBTI Advice to Dutch embassy in Ankara on collaboration local movement and EU on limitations on freedom of association and speech in Governarate of Ankara Advice to Dutch embassy in Warsaw on collaboration with LGBTI organizations in Belarus Advice to Dutch embassy in Kiev on collaboration with LGBTI organizations in Ukraine after violent attacks Advice to Dutch embassy in Tel Aviv on IDAHOT event in Jerusalem Advice to Dutch embassy in Cairo on IDAHOT event Advice to Dutch embassy in Tirana on IDAHOT event Advice to Dutch PM to OSCE on persecutions in Chechnya Advice to Dutch embassy in Kuala Lumpur on persecution of Lesbian couple Advice to Dutch embassy in Beirut on Crackdown on LGBTI conference

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of recommendations, concluding observations and resolutions made at regional and international fora with references to SOGIESC issues, LGBTI people and/or inclusive language.

description.narrative: Same as title. Note: Resolutions only refer to the end outcome and not the amendments in it.

comment.narrative: For UPR 27, 28 and 29 Tunisia (22/2), Indonesia (12/2), Ukraine (13/10), Sri Lanka (10/3), Pakistan (7/2), Ghana UPR 28 (20/4), Botswana (15/0) received recommendations Concluding Observations by CRPD for Morocoo

UPR Uzbekistan UPR Bangladesh UPR Azerbijan UPR Cameroon UPR Senegal UPR Congo UPR Central African Republic UPR Belize UPR Vietnam CSW Agreed Conclusions (inclusive language para's: in all their diversity, multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination (2 para's), gender-based violence linked to education, gender norms and stereotypes, underlying causes of gender-based violence ERC public statements on HR situation in Chechnya and at UN HRC and GA on report of the SOGI Independent Expert ICCPR Belize CEDAW Chile CEDAW Tajikistan CRC Sri Lanka

title.narrative: DD2 DD2: Number of laws, policies and norms that have been implemented for diverse and inclusive societies.

description.narrative: This indicator defines implementation as any new laws, revisions to existing laws, scratching of old laws and/or moratoriums.

comment.narrative: Guyana's crossdressing law deemed unconstitutional Canada announcing 1 mio CAD budget to international LGBTI movement Cape Verde as first African state joining the international coalition of states in the ERC
Pakistan Transgender & Intersex Protection Law

title.narrative: Number of Lobby & Advocacy related trainings provided.

description.narrative: This indicator is the sum total of trainings provided to activists and organisations on L&A. L&A (and related) trainings and workshops held with activists and organisations for capacity building purposes; workshops that have been delivered and panels that have been participated in at larger conferences; trainings provided on engagement mechanisms and techniques with international fora, for the purpose of subsequent engagement.

dimension.name: Number of L&A enagagement coaching provided to LGBTI activists for international and regional mechanisms.
Number of L&A skills trainings provided as part of a capacity building trajectory for international and regional mechanisms.
Number of workshops, panels and side-events organised/particiated in for capacity building and sensitisation of audience.

comment.narrative: 1. Intensive trajectories (UPR) for Uzbekistan, Bangladesh, Azerbaijan, Senegal, Congo, CAR, Belize (2), Vietnam (2) for ICCPR - Belize and CEDAW - Chile . Human Rights Mechanisms Training in Africa (PAI) and Asia (ILGA Asia). LBTI caucus coordination meetings to strategise at CSW. ERC civil society pre conference, Vancouver - lead a panel on previous conference and a regional strategy session. ERC civil society calls to coordinate, strategise, on structure and selection of conference participants. Intensive trajectory to CSW and NGO Forum participation, HRD from Kazakhstan. Training on OSCE/HDIM for Central Asian activists together with Labrys regional resource centre. 2. AIDS2018 in Amsterdam: LGBTI Networking Zone at the Global Village by COC and partners (PREPNu, PROUD, TNN, NNID), 2 sessions on Yogyakarta Principles +10 (NL w/ TNN & NNID; ENG w/ GATE & ARC) and session on engaging with the UPR on HIV (w/ Aids Alliance and MPact) L&A sessions organised on L&A during the S.E.A.R.C.H. consolidation workshop in Pretoria, S.A. Public LGBTI side event and LGBTI fishbowl session at WMG during HLPF in New York. Meeting dinner of 3 LGBTI HRDs with Dutch Minister van Engelshoven, ERC Conference, Vancouver. Side event on response and non-response to violence against LGBT people in Central Asia at HDIM 2018. 3. UPR SOGIESC Advocacy Weeks. International Advocay Week New York.

dimension.name: Number of L&A enagagement coaching provided to LGBTI activists for international and regional mechanisms.
Number of L&A skills trainings provided as part of a capacity building trajectory for international and regional mechanisms.
Number of workshops, panels and side-events organised/particiated in for capacity building and sensitisation of audience.
Number of L&A enagagement coaching provided to LGBTI activists for international and regional mechanisms.
Number of L&A skills trainings provided as part of a capacity building trajectory for international and regional mechanisms.
Number of workshops, panels and side-events organised/particiated in for capacity building and sensitisation of audience.

title.narrative: DD2 DD2: Number of policies, laws and resolutions harmful to the LGBTI community and/or inclusive language that have been successfully blocked.

description.narrative: This indicator measures the number of laws/policies/norms that have been blocked in country (through civil society pressure) or through voting against resolutions at international fora.

comment.narrative: Harmful ammendements blocked of the Death Penalty resolution voted on during HRC 35

Persecutions in Chechnya temporarily stopped after interventions at OSCE permanent council and international pressure Arbitrarily arrested gay men and trans persons released after interventions at OSCE permanent council and statement by 3 UN mandate holders Ban on LGBTI events in Ankara lifted

title.narrative: Mobilised LGBTI Movement.

description.narrative: LGBTI organisations need to cooperate to reach their joint goals, while also respecting their diversity. Change starts when they connect, begin exchanging information and become a mobilised LGBTI movement. It is when they are linked to non-LGBTI stakeholders and to broader civil society organisations that change becomes possible in society.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of advocacy initiatives carried out by grassroots organisations, community based organisations and CSOs to improve, change or influence relevant laws, policies and/or societal norms.

description.narrative: CBOs and activists supported through PRIDE hold causeries, dialogues, sensitisation trainings and the likes on various topics related to being LGBTI, SOGIESC, inclusive service provision, discriminatory biases in public practices etc. These initiatives are held with various stakeholders (religious leaders, service providers, schools, police, local governments and ministries). The aim of these dialogues is to sensitise the targeted actors on LGBTI and SOGIESC issues, and change/improve or influence their actions. Through this indicator, we measure how many such initiatives have been undertaken. This indicator does not encompass advocacy activities carried out at international spaces such as the UN, UPR etc. but only in-country/regional level engagement.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of times unique alliances between different organisations were formed.

description.narrative: Grassroots organisations, CBOs and other CSOs come together for multiple reasons in order to cooperate and/or align efforts with broader movements - human rights, LGBTI, women's rights, etc. In some instances these cooperations manifest in the way of joint pressure campaigns on governments and research undertakings or through network expansion in remote areas of the country. For the LGBTI movement this helps build and grow a base of allies outside the community and also to increase visibility and develop solidarity with cross-cutting intersectional issues. This indicator measures the number of times unique alliances of two or more partners other relevant organisations and/or actors were formed.

title.narrative: DD3 DD3: Number of targeted actors adopting LGBTI and SOGIESC friendly terminology, rhetoric and framing.

description.narrative: On the basis of the initiatives carried out under indicator 10, this indicator measures successful adoption of terminology, rhetoric and framing on LGBTI/SOGIESC issues by those targeted individuals, groups and/or institutions.

title.narrative: Empowered LGBTI Individuals

description.narrative: Social change starts with individual LGBTI people who no longer accept being marginalised but decide to take action. Individual stories raise public awareness and expose the level of exclusion in society. Empowered LGBTI individuals serve as role models for others, and their actions form important steps in the creation of LGBTI communities.

title.narrative: Number of LGBTI and allies, community members, service deliverers, and/or leaders educated and sensitised on LGBTI issues, who can carry forward the messages further.

description.narrative: CBOs and activists supported through PRIDE hold causeries, dialogues, sensitisation trainings and the likes on various topics related to being LGBTI, SOGIESC, inclusive service provision, discriminatory biases in public practices, self-esteem and acceptance etc. Through this indicator, we measure how many people have been reached through these initiatives.

title.narrative: Number of knowledge dissemination activities taken on to bring the LGBTI community together, sensitise and inform them on their legal rights, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression and sex characteristics.

description.narrative: This indicator measures the number of knowledge dissemination tools (eg. legal handbooks) created and distributed, activities held (eg. soccer games, cooking classes etc.) amongst the community to inform, sensitise and/or educate them on relevant issues. These activities are under the pretext of self-esteem building, empowerment trainings and the tools serve the purpose of awareness raising and information sharing within the community.

title.narrative: Strong LGBTI Communities

description.narrative: Strong communities start when front liners take action and bring individuals together. Communities start as small-scale social events and are often based on positive drivers: contact, entertainment or a shared interest. Creating a safe space is essential in starting communities.

title.narrative: Number of people reached through LGBTI focused events.

description.narrative: This indicator measures an approximate number of people reached through the events under 6.1.

title.narrative: DD4 DD4: Number of crisis response measures taken up.

description.narrative: At certain unfortunate moments, there arises a need for emergency and crisis response measures to be taken up by the LGBTI community in countries. These responses, while not a planned intervention under PRIDE, are supported by COC with the goal of building resilience within the community and extending solidarity in dire times of need. These responses include public statements issued, back-door diplomacy with embassies on the ground, emergency shelter provision, legal-aid services, medical and psychological help and provision of basic services such as food and water. Through this indicator we measure the number of such responses that have been deployed both by COC and its partners.

title.narrative: Number of safe spaces created.

description.narrative: Physical shelter creation in-country for LGBTI individuals to gather, exchange and/or seek safety.

title.narrative: Number of events the LGBTI community hosted/participated in.

description.narrative: Using public spaces to raise awareness and visibility of LGBTI issues is an effective way to mobilise, build communities and make public statements. Being visible publicly in many countries is in itself a significant achievement due to threats posed by social and political climates. This indicator measures the number of times the LGBTI community was supported in being publicly visible through events such as Pride, IDAHOT, Women's Day, Carnival etc.
